section_01.section_summary: Joshua Reynolds was a talented and determined individual who was born to succeed, with a rare mixture of talent, industry, and common sense. He is considered one of the greatest painters of the 18th century, and his work had a significant impact on the development of English art. Reynolds' journey to Italy, where he studied and copied the works of great masters, was a pivotal moment in his career, and he never forgot the debt he owed to the art of the old masters. Upon his return to England, Reynolds established himself as a prominent painter and played a key role in the founding of the Royal Academy. Through his work and teachings, Reynolds left a lasting legacy in the art world, and his paintings continue to be celebrated for their beauty and technique.

[LEXICON]: Some words are used in unclear contexts

section_02.section_summary: Sir Joshua Reynolds was a successful portrait painter who enjoyed the patronage of high society and was able to raise his prices without losing clients. He was a man of many interests and friendships, including with notable figures such as Dr. Johnson, Garrick, and Burke, which helped to broaden his intellectual and artistic horizons. Despite having some personal flaws, Reynolds was able to conquer the temptations of his success and remained focused on his art, completing numerous portraits throughout his career. He played a significant role in the establishment of the Royal Academy, although he took a diplomatic approach and avoided getting involved in the intrigues and controversies surrounding its founding. Ultimately, Reynolds' legacy as one of the greatest British portrait painters remains unchanged, despite his personal imperfections, and his contributions to the art world continue to be celebrated.

[TRANSITION]: lack of smooth connections between paragraphs

section_03.section_summary: Sir Joshua Reynolds was a prominent figure in the art world, and his contributions to the exhibitions of the Society of Artists were widely admired. He had a large circle of friends and acquaintances, and his home in Leicester Square was open to many notable figures of the time. Reynolds' painting style had become strong and firm, but he struggled with achieving permanent coloring, which led to some of his works fading over time. Despite this, he left a glorious heritage to his country, and his portraits are characterized by a sane and optimistic note, capturing the best in his sitters. Reynolds' personal life was marked by self-control and virtue, which sometimes led to speculation and criticism from his biographers, particularly regarding his relationship with the artist Angelica Kaufmann.

section_04.section_summary: After receiving a knighthood in 1769, Sir Joshua Reynolds' social status and reputation continued to grow, and he became more selective with his portrait commissions. He remained a prominent figure in the art world, and his Discourses on art are still studied and admired today. In the 1780s, Reynolds traveled to the Low Countries, where he was inspired by the works of Dutch masters, and he continued to produce notable portraits, including those of Mrs. Siddons and the Duchess of Devonshire. However, his artistic career came to a sudden end in 1789 when he lost the use of one eye while working at his easel. Despite his retirement from painting, Reynolds' legacy as a leading artist of his time remained, and his works continue to be celebrated for their beauty and insight.

section_05.section_summary: Sir Joshua Reynolds spent his final years preparing for his death, sustained by memories of the past and surrounded by friends. He delivered his final address to students in 1790 and sat for a portrait by the Swedish artist von Breda, before passing away in 1792 at the age of 69. Reynolds' art is still admired today, and his ability to assimilate and learn from other masters, such as Rembrandt and Titian, contributed to his success. He sought to unite the excellences of various artists, while avoiding their defects, and developed a unique style through years of study and practice. Reynolds' portraits are notable for their beauty and technique, although some critics argue that they often lack a sense of humanity, particularly in his depictions of women and children.

section_06.section_summary: Sir Joshua Reynolds' paintings of women and children lack a sense of intimacy, suggesting he had no deep interest in them. In contrast, his portraits of men, such as Admiral Keppel and Charles James Fox, showcase his exceptional skill and ability to capture their character and essence. Reynolds' vision was comprehensive, and his portraits were masterful in their simplicity and directness, making it difficult for other artists to approach the same subjects. However, many of his canvases have not aged well, with some losing their original colors or being restored, which can make it challenging to appreciate his work at its best. Despite this, Reynolds' name and fame remain a source of pride in British art and a subject of admiration worldwide.
